text:
"All great men are criminals," Raskolnikov said, his voice steady. 

Razumihin frowned. "What do you mean?"

"They break ancient laws to create new ones," Raskolnikov explained. 

"But at what cost?" Razumihin asked, bewildered.

"Bloodshed, often innocent lives," Raskolnikov replied. "Yet they change the world."

Razumihin shook his head. "Thatâ€™s a grim view."

"Is it not true?" Raskolnikov challenged. "To rise above the ordinary, one must defy."

"But why must it involve crime?" Razumihin pressed.

"Because to remain ordinary is to submit," Raskolnikov answered, a hint of defiance in his eyes.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov argues that all great leaders and innovators are inherently criminals for transgressing established laws to create change.
